    Uncoupling the Structure–Activity Relationships of β2 Adrenergic Receptor Ligands from Membrane Binding

    • Callum J. Dickson*†
      • , 
    • Viktor Hornak*†
      • ,

    Abstract

    Ligand binding to membrane proteins may be significantly influenced by the interaction of ligands with the membrane. In particular, the microscopic ligand concentration within the membrane surface solvation layer may exceed that in bulk solvent, resulting in overestimation of the intrinsic protein–ligand binding contribution to the apparent/measured affinity. Using published binding data for a set of small molecules with the β2 adrenergic receptor, we demonstrate that deconvolution of membrane and protein binding contributions allows for improved structure–activity relationship analysis and structure-based drug design. Molecular dynamics simulations of ligand bound membrane protein complexes were used to validate binding poses, allowing analysis of key interactions and binding site solvation to develop structure–activity relationships of β2 ligand binding. The resulting relationships are consistent with intrinsic binding affinity (corrected for membrane interaction). The successful structure-based design of ligands targeting membrane proteins may require an assessment of membrane affinity to uncouple protein binding from membrane interactions.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Integral membrane proteins, and G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) in particular, participate in a wide array of cellular functions and thereby constitute a large class of pharmacologically important targets.(1) Early drug discovery is highly dependent on measured structure–activity relationships (SAR), the interpretation of which is guided in many cases by ligand- (e.g., pharmacophore, QSAR) and structure-based models. It is implicitly assumed in all cases that measured/apparent and true activities are approximately equivalent. However, the validity of this assumption can vary on a case-by-case basis, depending on both the nature of the target and the experimental methods. Membrane protein binding is typically measured using membrane preparations due to difficulties in isolating membrane embedded proteins from their natural environment. It is apparent that membrane proteins are “solvated” by a combination of water and phospholipids and other species partitioned in the phospholipid bilayer (e.g., cholesterol). Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that ligand binding is governed by three-way interactions with water, protein, and membrane.
    Because of this increased complexity, it is likely that the pharmacology of drug binding to membrane embedded proteins, such as the β2-adrenergic receptor GPCR (β2-AR), is more intricate than drug interaction with a soluble target. This may complicate the interpretation of binding data for membrane proteins and thus SAR built on such data. It has been proposed that the binding of drugs targeting membrane receptors may be influenced by a number of membrane related phenomena. A “microkinetic” model(2-5) suggests that the accumulation of drug inside or in the vicinity of the membrane compartment acts as a depot, increasing local drug concentration around the target. Slow release from the membrane depot may account for a longer duration of action.(6, 7) The “reduction in dimensionality” effect(8, 9) may also need to be considered, whereby ligands move from 3D diffusion in solution to 2D lateral diffusion in the membrane, possibly resulting in an increased drug–receptor collision rate. The extent of this effect would depend on factors such as the drug surface density and 2D lateral diffusion coefficient. Alternatively, an “exosite” model(10, 11) accounts for the extended duration of action of long-acting β2-adrenoceptor agonists by proposing that the side chain of the agonist anchors into the membrane, or some other exosite, allowing the activating warhead to flip in and out of the binding site. Lastly, a “rebinding” model(12, 13) proposes that dissociated drug is able to quickly reassociate with the same or other nearby receptor, delaying escape from the cell surface.
    While no single model necessarily describes all membrane protein–ligand binding cases, we adopt the microkinetic model in this work. Considerable evidence suggests that certain molecules partition or adsorb in or on bilayers, thereby enhancing their copy number proximal to membrane protein binding sites and promoting slow return back to the central compartment (where clearance occurs). Although the exact mechanism underlying the longer duration of action of certain β2 ligands remains controversial,(14) the microkinetic model is consistent with computational simulations performed by Szczuka et al., suggesting that it adequately explains long-lasting β2-AR stimulation due to ligand enrichment in the membrane(15) and the identification of a tissue binding site for β2 agonists distinct from the β2-AR via radio-ligand binding.(16) Conversely, the exosite model does not account for the similarly long duration of action of the β2 agonists formoterol and salmeterol despite the shorter nonpolar side chain of formoterol.(17-20)
    In addition to affecting the pharmacokinetics of a ligand, drug–membrane interactions may also obscure the true intrinsic binding affinity of ligands for a membrane embedded target making experimental measurements of membrane receptor binding difficult to interpret. Typical amphiphilic drug molecules may absorb onto the membrane surface, causing an enhancement in local concentration around the receptor and observed on-rate to the target. The molecules with high membrane affinity show higher observed target binding (lower Kd) than is really occurring; the measured receptor occupancy, and thus Kd, is driven by a high local concentration rather than the assumed bulk concentration of ligand.(4) High membrane association can therefore obscure low intrinsic affinity for the protein. This effect also skews SAR to favoring more lipophilic ligands as an apparent way to increase affinity. In such cases, only by uncoupling intrinsic protein binding from membrane association is it possible to build a meaningful SAR for membrane protein binding.
    Recently, Sykes et al.(5) investigated the influence of a membrane compartment on membrane receptor binding by separately determining the membrane affinity and β2-AR binding for a number of β2 agonists and antagonists, using the immobilized artificial membrane (IAM) HPLC method,(21) together with radioligand competition assays on membrane preparations, with results suggesting that the apparent measured Kd is indeed influenced by ligand–membrane interactions. Cationic amphiphilic drugs, such as those considered in the present work, have been found via surface plasmon resonance to bind to the surface of liposomes, with the binding affinity dependent on the drug structure and lipid type.(22) The assumption used in this work is that such membrane association is reasonably well captured by the IAM experiment. It has previously been found that IAM chromatography accurately predicts the promiscuity of PET imaging drugs to bind nonspecifically to membranes.(23) Once KIAM is determined, the intrinsic receptor binding (Kdint) may be calculated by subtracting KIAM from the observed target Kd (Kdobs).(9, 24, 25) To facilitate the understanding of the microkinetic model in this work, we make a distinction between membrane association and membrane partitioning. While association with the membrane helps to increase the ligand concentration around the membrane and the protein target, membrane partitioning effectively removes the ligand from the solution phase and makes it unavailable for binding (excluding the possibility of binding from the membrane compartment). The essence of the binding model is captured in Figure 1.
    In this work, we have used all-atom molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of the β2-AR embedded in a fully solvated phospholipid bilayer model, together with water structure analysis, to study the intrinsic binding contributions (Kdint versus Kdobs) in the β2 ligand data set of Sykes et al. The modeled binding modes were used in conjunction with solvation analysis (from our in-house WATMD software(26, 27)) to explore the SAR against observed versus intrinsic affinity (Kdint, derived from Kdobs and KIAM). We demonstrate that correction of observed receptor binding affinity for membrane association is essential for deriving meaningful SAR needed for ligand- or structure-based lead optimization.
    Our study is based on the binding and kinetic data of a number of β2 agonists and antagonists for the inactive/G protein-uncoupled form of β2-AR reported by Sykes et al.(5) In that work, association and dissociation rates of the ligands were measured using a kinetic competition radioligand binding method on Chinese hamster ovary cell membrane preparations expressing β2-AR. Membrane affinity (KIAM) was estimated using an immobilized artificial membrane (IAM) HPLC column,(21) which comprises phosphatidylcholine analogues immobilized on silica as a chromatography phase to mimic a cell membrane. To account for enhanced ligand concentration around the β2-AR receptor due to membrane interactions, kinetic association rates were corrected as koncorr = kon/KIAM.(5) This allowed calculation of the “true” or intrinsic binding affinity via Kdint = koff/koncorr, which is equivalent to a simpler expression:(1)
    Taking the logarithmic form then yields Kdint as the observed binding affinity minus the membrane affinity, pKdint = pKdobs – log KIAM. Interestingly, the correction for membrane binding is of the same form as lipophilic efficiency (LiPE = pIC50 – log P).(28)
    For the discussion of how membrane interactions affect functional versus binding assays, we refer to the Hill–Langmuir equation describing receptor occupancy ρ as a function of ligand concentration [L] and ligand affinity to the receptor Kd:(2)
    Note that according to eq 2, receptor occupancy depends on the free ligand concentration [L] and binding constant Kd. Lacking accurate knowledge of [L] at the binding site, there is no way to distinguish the relative contributions of free concentration and Kd to occupancy solely on the basis of functional assay data.
    All ligand structures used in this study, along with Kdobs, Kdint, and KIAM, are shown in Figure 2. Most compounds are racemic, but were modeled with the same stereochemistry (R for salmeterol series and S for cyanopindolol series) of the canonical β-hydroxy-amine motif within each group of analogues. Therefore, the measured Kd can shift slightly (about 2-fold as a consequence of the inactive enantiomer) but likely in the same direction within a series. The cis-stereoisomer was assumed for nadolol at the tetralin ring.
    To demonstrate the effect of KIAM on intrinsic Kdint, let us consider the following illustrative example. The observed binding affinity of salmeterol to β2-AR is Kdobs = 0.3 nM. However, this ligand has high membrane association (log KIAM = 3.5), creating a high local concentration around the receptor and an apparent enhanced binding affinity observed experimentally under the assumption of uniform bulk concentration. To correct for this effect, the intrinsic binding Kdint may be derived from eq 1 as Kdint = 0.3 × 10–9 × 103.5 = 1100 nM. High membrane association of salmeterol therefore obscures its much lower intrinsic binding Kdint.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The primary objective of our study was to assess whether direct protein–receptor binding is best reflected in the calculated Kdint or experimental Kdobs values based on observed interactions in our MD simulations and WATMD analysis results. Groups of structurally related ligands were selected based on the published binding data.
    All ligands modeled display conserved interactions between the β-hydroxy-amine motif on the ligand tails and β2-AR Asp113 and Asn312 residues at the front of the binding pocket, a common anchor shared by many β2 antagonists, inverse agonists, and agonists.(29) The majority of residues forming the remainder of the narrow binding pocket are hydrophobic, with the exception of certain polar residues at the rear: Ser203, Ser204, Ser207, and Tyr199 on H5, Asn293 on H6, and Thr118 on H3.
    The first example examines structurally related β2 agonists isoprenaline, salbutamol, and the long-acting salmeterol, for which membrane and receptor binding data are available(5) (see Figure 2). The observed 700-fold higher potency of the β2 agonist salmeterol in comparison to the structurally related agonists isoprenaline and salbutamol (Kdobs) is found to be solely due to membrane binding; salmeterol has far higher membrane affinity, and upon correcting for this, all three agonists have comparable Kdint values for the inactive form of β2-AR (Figure 2). The SAR of salmeterol is necessarily weighted toward higher membrane association to a greater extent than the other compounds, which can mislead SAR interpretation in the absence of this knowledge.
    Our structural analysis suggests that the similar intrinsic activities likely result from the catechol (isoprenaline) and saligenin (salbutamol and salmeterol) groups of the agonists forming similar hydrogen bonding networks to the serine residue Ser203 and to Thr118 via a bridging water molecule at the rear of the binding pocket (Figure 3) in addition to conserved anchor interactions to Asp113 and Asn312. A docked pose of salmeterol is able to create an additional hydrogen bond with β2-AR (Figure 3, circled in red), however this does not appear to translate into higher intrinsic binding affinity, possibly due to the entropic penalty encountered on binding this highly flexible ligand. In this first example, traditional analysis would point to salmeterol as having the strongest binding to β2-AR (Kdobs = 0.3 nM), however, the membrane correction puts all three ligands at roughly equal binding affinity (Kdint = 740–1400 nM), which is more consistent from the point of view of very similar ligand–receptor interactions in the binding pocket. Using Kdint as a primary binding affinity indicator changes our perception of what ligand features are important for binding.
    The three β2-AR antagonist analogues atenolol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol contain an aromatic ring with a β-hydroxy-amine tail, differing solely in their headgroup substituents; atenolol contains an amide chain, metoprolol an ether, and bisoprolol a diether (Figure 2). The observed binding affinity of atenolol, metoprolol, and bisoprolol are virtually equivalent, with all three having a measured Kdobs in the 100–300 nM range. However, after correcting for membrane binding, atenolol becomes the most potent, having an intrinsic Kdint which is roughly 10-fold improved over either metoprolol or bisoprolol. Upon examination of the modeled binding modes (Figure 4), this separation in Kdint values appears sensible, as atenolol is able to form an interaction network between the amide side chain and Ser207 and Thr118, in addition to the standard anchor interactions to Asp113 and Asn312. Conversely, metoprolol finds only a single additional hydrogen bond between the ether chain and Tyr199, and bisoprolol displays a single additional hydrogen bond between the diether and Ser207. Furthermore, the longer, flexible ether chains of metoprolol and bisoprolol may potentially lose greater conformational entropy upon binding in comparison to the shorter amide side chain of atenolol. In this example, we observe the reverse scenario compared to the salmeterol series. While we start with roughly equipotent observed binding affinities, membrane correction singles out atenolol as the tightest binder to β2-AR. Again, corrected Kdint values change how we interpret the SAR in this series of analogues.
    The cyanopindolol β2 antagonist series consists of cyanopindolol, CGP12177, nadolol, propranolol, and ICI-118,551 (Figure 2). The observed binding affinity of cyanopindolol is initially 700-fold more potent than the structurally similar ligands CGP12177, nadolol, propranolol, and ICI-118,551. Nadolol exhibits the lowest potency of the series, with CGP12177, propranolol, and ICI-118,551 being roughly equipotent. After correction for membrane binding, cyanopindolol remains the most potent, yet the ranking of the remainder of the series shifts as follows: CGP12177 and nadolol display higher binding affinity than the hydrophobic core bearing ligands of propranolol and ICI-118,551.
    The stronger intrinsic binding propensity of cyanopindolol, CGP12177, and nadolol over that of propranolol and ICI-118,551 is revealed on analysis of their binding modes to β2-AR (Figure 5): the former ligands can make additional hydrogen bonds to the protein, which the hydrophobic cores of propranolol and ICI-118,551 cannot achieve. Cyanopindolol and CGP12177 are able to form stable hydrogen bonds to Ser203, while the hydroxyl groups of nadolol make hydrogen bonds to Ser204 and high occupancy water. The ∼30-fold higher binding affinity of cyanopindolol in comparison to the structurally similar CGP12177 cannot be explained from direct receptor–ligand interactions; however, WATMD analysis reveals that CGP12177 remains partially solvated in the binding pocket, while cyanopindolol does not. The water next to the cyclic urea of CGP12177 forms ∼3 hydrogen bonds (i.e., less than the average 3.6 bonds in bulk water), suggesting H-bond/enthalpic depletion; furthermore, it is trapped at the rear of the binding pocket so it should pay a high entropic penalty. The cyano group of cyanopindolol efficiently fills this space in the binding pocket by displacing this energetically unfavorable water, resulting in higher binding affinity. A similar result was reported by Pearlstein et al.(30) in a WaterMap study of p38α kinase, in which trapped water was displaced by the naphthyl group of one inhibitor but not the phenyl of another. Solvation with occupancy higher than bulk is also seen in this region of the binding pocket in the nadolol, propranolol, and ICI-118,551 results. In the cyanopindolol example, reranking of ligands based on Kdint is more subtle than in the previous two examples, yet still significant, especially for propranolol and ICI-118,551, which started as more potent binders based on their observed affinities (Kdobs) but ended up as the weakest binders upon uncoupling their intrinsic binding affinity (Kdint) from membrane interactions.
    The binding kinetics of these β2 antagonists may be explained by how ligand binding perturbs the water structure inside the protein pocket. Upon correction of the kinetic data for membrane binding, all five ligands have very similar kon values of 0.33–3.11 × 106 M–1 min–1 (Supporting Information, Table S1).(5) The higher Kdint of cyanopindolol is due to far slower koff than the remainder of the series (cyanopindolol koff 0.002 min–1, CGP12177 0.05 min–1, nadolol 0.14 min–1, propranolol 0.46 min–1, and ICI-118,551 0.21 min–1). This is possibly due to the efficient replacement of solvation by the cyano group from the unbound protein upon ligand binding, a premise supported by the fact that a WATMD analysis of the unbound protein reveals high water occupancy at the rear of the binding pocket precisely at the position of the cyano group (Figure 5). The relation between solvation and association and dissociation rates has been previously studied(30-32) and is an active area of research in our group.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Modeling of receptor–ligand interactions, combined with binding pocket solvation analysis, may adequately guide SAR interpretation in cases where direct protein–ligand interactions are known to predominate in measured protein–ligand binding affinity. However, the effects of membrane binding on Kdobs cannot be directly measured in vitro due to the practical limitations of expressing properly folded membrane proteins isolated from the phospholipid environment, thereby preventing direct measurements on membrane free protein. Although variable levels of ligand–membrane binding across a series of receptor ligands can confound the interpretation of experimentally determined SAR, indirect methods for deconvoluting Kdobs and Kmem, including KIAM combined with appropriate structure-based modeling, can be used to a first approximation. Although this work is concerned with β2-AR binding, membrane interactions are expected to affect binding to all integral membrane protein binding sites. Exploring the SAR and corresponding binding modes for larger chemical series with KIAM and Kdobs measurements, for either the β2-AR or other membrane protein, would further our understanding on the need to uncouple receptor and membrane binding.
    In this work, we performed a qualitative analysis of interactions and solvation of several series of ligands with the β2-AR receptor. We compared interaction patterns to their experimental binding affinities (Kdobs), as well as to membrane corrected intrinsic binding affinities (Kdint), concluding that receptor–ligand interactions are more consistent with the intrinsic binding affinities Kdint rather than observed values (Kdobs). Prospective quantitative predictions of intrinsic binding affinities remain challenging even with state-of-the-art energy scoring functions.(33, 34) More rigorous methods based on free energy calculations(35, 36) have experienced a recent resurgence and have shown progress toward a more reliable quantitative prediction of free energies of binding.(37-39)
    Drug discovery targeted at GPCRs is predominantly driven by functional, rather than binding assays, and as such membrane binding is an important consideration in the interpretation of SAR based on functional data. Functional readouts are downstream from binding and receptor activation and therefore more closely tied to therapeutic effects in vivo. Functional response, which is directly related to receptor occupancy, is fully determined by intrinsic receptor binding (Kdint) when the ligand concentration is known (eq 2). However, ligand–membrane interactions, which are implicit to the microkinetic model, obscure the concentration of the ligand in the target compartment. The ligand concentration can be enriched at the receptor binding site due to ligand–membrane interactions, resulting in a greater response than would have been expected based on the applied “bulk” ligand concentration in the functional assay. In such cases, the desired receptor occupancy is achieved via weaker than expected Kdint (i.e., Kdint > Kdobs). We can imagine a hypothetical example in which two ligands, A and B, elicit an equivalent functional response and therefore are assumed to have the same intrinsic receptor occupancy. Let us further assume that, due to membrane association, ligand A has 100-fold higher local concentration in the target compartment than ligand B. Ligand A can now achieve the same receptor occupancy with 100-times weaker intrinsic affinity Kdint. Therefore, ligand A achieves the same receptor occupancy due to its higher concentration at the expense of its weaker intrinsic binding (Kdint). The interpretation of the SAR for ligands A and B would therefore be very different once we understand that the same magnitude of functional response can result from significantly different intrinsic affinities (Kdint).
    In this work, we have adopted the membrane receptor binding model as used by Sykes et al.,(5) whereby ligands with higher levels of membrane affinity accumulate at the membrane/water interface. Receptor on-rate is enhanced by enrichment of the ligand concentration within the target compartment (appearing as more potent Kdobs). It is assumed that ligand enrichment at the membrane surface translates to increased concentration in the target compartment (dark-blue zone in Figure 1) and remains available for binding to the receptor. Furthermore, it is assumed that KIAM is a reasonable measure of this membrane association. By the same token, membrane interactions can work to lower the free ligand concentration in the target compartment, depending on the nature of the ligand: highly lipophilic compounds may become trapped within the membrane for extended periods of time, while highly polar molecules may accumulate in the solution bulk phase. Concentration lowering effects are not captured by our current model (Figure 1), which assumes that the ligand concentration is always enhanced in the target compartment. As a future extension of this work, we plan to develop a more complete kinetic model of β2-AR binding that incorporates both receptor–ligand and membrane–ligand binding kinetics (see Figure 6). We expect that the optimal KIAM is neither too low (i.e., reflecting low or no enrichment) nor too high (i.e., reflecting high membrane partitioning, where the membrane acts as a ligand sink). The effect of target compartment enrichment may be overestimated for ligands with higher KIAM values used in our study (e.g., salmeterol), resulting in overcorrection of the intrinsic binding affinity (Kdint). A solution to this problem necessitates consideration of both membrane–ligand and protein–ligand binding kinetics (Figure 6). While this scheme is more realistic, it is also more complex, requiring experimental determination of all kinetic rate constants depicted in the model.
    Kinetics characterization is critically important for translating in vitro data to the cellular setting in vivo,(40-42) and for this reason, we have been strongly advocating the use of a structure–kinetics paradigm in drug discovery for some time. Several studies reported by Pearlstein et al. point to the critical role of water in governing structure–kinetics relationships.(30-32) We have used these principles to predict the structure–kinetics relationships of the β2-AR agonists and antagonists based on the overlay between the docked compounds and the solvation structure of apo β2-AR calculated using WATMD. The results suggest that compounds with experimentally determined slow dissociation from the receptor (i.e., slow koff) cause efficient transfer of enthalpically unfavorable solvation from the binding site to bulk solvent (e.g., cyanopindolol compared with CGP12177).
    Some GPCRs, including CXCR4, rhodopsin,(43) and cannabinoid receptors,(44) are believed to contain membrane-exposed binding sites that are only accessible from within the bilayer (i.e., the bilayer serves as the target compartment). In such cases, high membrane partitioning (i.e., fast k2 and slow k–2) should translate to faster receptor on-rates, and conversely, fast k–2 should translate to slower on-rates. On-rates may be further enhanced by more rapid rates of 2D lateral diffusion compared with diffusion in 3D volumes.(8, 9) Provisions for binding to membrane-exposed binding sites could be added to extend our model to other GPCRs (Figure 6). However, binding from the membrane compartment is clearly not the case for the β2-AR, whose transmembrane pocket entrance is extracellular, and whose endogenous ligand, epinephrine, is polar.(44, 45)
    While membrane association and partitioning can be pharmacologically beneficial, the trapping of amphiphilic compounds within membranes may also translate to high volumes of distribution in pharmacokinetic studies, which is typically associated with undesirably long lifetimes in the body and toxicity (e.g., phospholipidosis,(46) off-target effects(47, 48)). The degree of drug–membrane interaction as determined by IAM chromatography has been found to correlate well with phospholipidosis risk.(49) Cationic amphiphilic compounds are known to sequester in membranes, and some select phospholipogenics cause liver toxicity in preclinical species such as rats(50-53) and dogs(54) at higher dose levels.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Our study highlights the importance of deconvoluting membrane– and protein–ligand binding contributions to measured ligand binding data (Kdobs) for integral membrane proteins. Membrane affinity corrections can result in significant differences in the rank ordering of measured activity and SAR and greatly impact the direction of medicinal chemistry efforts. We have tested one such correction strategy consisting of using Kdobs together with measured membrane association (KIAM) to estimate the intrinsic binding affinity (Kdint) by cross-checking the Kdint against qualitative binding information derived from an in silico binding modes and solvation analysis.
    The microkinetic model has important implications for lead selection and optimization as well as pharmacokinetic studies. In particular, potent Kdobs resulting from a combination of weaker Kdint and high membrane association may translate to higher dosing requirements due to the on-rate driven nature of receptor occupancy in such cases. In other words, weak intrinsic affinity Kdint has to be compensated by higher concentration around the receptor to achieve the required receptor occupancy necessary for the functional response. Furthermore, rational lead optimization depends on understanding all of the different contributions to the observed in vitro potency and in vivo efficacy.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The experimental binding data used in the present work was measured using the inactive form of the β2-AR, thus all systems used inactive β2-AR crystal structure from PDB entry 2RH1 in the OPM orientation.(55, 56) All nonprotein molecules were deleted and only crystal waters inside the protein retained. The T4L loop required for crystallization purposes was deleted and replaced with the artificial loop from β2-AR PDB 4GBR, residues 230–238.(57) The resulting structure then underwent the Structure Preparation and Protonate 3D steps in MOE.(58) All protonation states of acidic/basic residues were then manually verified for consistency of the hydrogen-bonding network. His296 was δ protonated and His93, His172, His178, and His269 were in ε protonation state. To charge neutralize the system, solvent exposed, noninteracting residues Lys97, Lys227, and Lys232 on the protein surface were modeled in the neutral state. These residues were chosen to ensure that the centroid of overall charge distribution of the protein system was minimally perturbed.
    Initial solvating waters within the protein were placed using 3D-RISM,(59, 60) complementing retained crystal waters. The protein was inserted into a solvated lipid bilayer using the Charmm GUI.(61) A membrane consisting of 272 POPC lipids total was built around the protein (136 per leaflet), and the system was further solvated with a 20 Å water layer above and below the protein. This number of lipid molecules was required to ensure that there will be at least three lipid layers between the protein and the edge of the periodic box. The final PDB of the membrane protein system was converted to AMBER format using the charmmlipid2amber script.(62)
    MOE was used for initial placement of atenolol, bisoprolol, metoprolol, cyanopindolol, nadolol, propranolol, and CGP12177 in the model protein structure based on the crystal structure of β2-AR bound to carazolol (PDB code 2RH1(55)). Isoprenaline and salbutamol were built using the structure of adrenaline from 4LDO(63) as a starting point. After building the ligands in a structurally intuitive manner, using the conserved interactions between the ligand β-hydroxy-amine motif and β2-AR Asp113 and Asn312 residues at the front of the binding pocket as an anchor, the coordinates of the ligand molecule were minimized with MOE. Salmeterol was docked into the β2-AR binding pocket using Glide SP from Schrödinger,(64) and the top scoring pose was selected. The coordinates of the ligand ICI-118,551 were obtained from the X-ray structure 3NY8.(65)
    All systems underwent molecular dynamics simulation with an identical protocol using AMBER 14(62) and PMEMD CUDA(66-68) on a GPU cluster. The protein was modeled with the ff12SB protein force field,(69) ligands with the [email protected] force field(70) and conformationally averaged AM1-BCC charges,(26, 71-73) and lipids were modeled using the AMBER Lipid14 force field(74-76) and water using the TIP3P model.(77)
    First, the system was energy minimized for 10000 steps, of which the first 5000 steps used the steepest descent method and the remaining steps used the conjugate gradient method.(78) The system was then heated from 0 to 100 K using Langevin dynamics(79) within a 5 ps constant volume run, with restraints on the protein, ligand, and lipids (force constant 10 kcal/mol/Å2). The volume was then allowed to change freely and the temperature increased to 303 K with a Langevin collision frequency of γ = 1 ps–1, and anisotropic Berendsen control of the pressure(80) around 1 atm was applied by coupling the periodic box with a time constant of 2 ps for 100 ps. The same restraint of 10 kcal/mol/Å2 was maintained on the protein, ligand and lipid molecules.
    The pressure relaxation time was then reduced to 1 ps, restraints were removed on lipids only and the system left to equilibrate for 5 ns in the constant pressure and constant temperature ensemble (NPT). Three-dimensional periodic boundary conditions with the usual minimum image convention were employed. Bonds involving hydrogen were constrained using the SHAKE algorithm,(81) allowing a 2 fs time-step. Particle mesh Ewald was used to treat all electrostatic interactions(82) beyond a cutoff of 10 Å. A long-range analytical dispersion correction was applied to energy and pressure. The system was then run for 5 ns with restraints on the ligand and protein backbone atoms followed by a further 5 ns NPT with restraints on the ligand and protein C-α atoms only. Finally, all restraints were removed and a 10 ns NPT production run performed. Trajectory coordinates were recorded every 10 ps.
    To collect trajectory data to allow solvation analysis using our in-house program WATMD, simulations were extended for a further 10 ns in NPT, with coordinates recorded every 0.25 ps to properly sample water positions. A total of five repeat WATMD simulations (10 ns each) were performed to validate the convergence of the solvation structure. The ligands remained stable in all simulations (see Supporting Information, Figure S1 for root-mean-square deviation plots).
    All structural analyses of the resulting trajectories were performed with CPPTRAJ.(83) Representative binding modes were obtained by calculating time averaged structures from the full production runs using CPPTRAJ. The average structures take flexibility into account and may therefore result in seemingly structurally distorted depictions. All modeling figures were generated with PYMOL,(84) depicted hydrogen bonds using the default PYMOL definition of 3.6 Å distance cutoff and 63° angle cutoff.
    A number of methodologies have been developed which attempt to quantify the crucial role that water plays in molecular recognition.(59, 85-91) In this work, our in-house tool WATMD(26) was used on each of the 10 ns trajectories with 0.25 ps frame rate to study solvation of the binding site. WATMD calculates the time-averaged distribution of atomic solvation, which essentially describes the occupancy of water at discrete positions in the binding pocket. Key advantages of WATMD compared to other implementations are (1) the protein conformation is not fixed during the MD simulations, and (2) water occupancy in the vicinity of the protein is calculated relative to water occupancy in bulk water. For a more detailed description of the methodology, see ref 26.
    By studying the number of hydrogen bonds made by each high occupancy water site identified via WATMD (for this work, only those sites with occupancy higher than 2× bulk were considered), it is possible to qualitatively classify each of these sites as either enthalpically favorable or enthalpically unfavorable with respect to bulk water. Specifically, for TIP3P water simulations at physiological conditions, we consider that those solvation sites that make less than ∼3.6 hydrogen bonds are unfavorable, while those that make 3.6 or more hydrogen bonds are favorable. The value of 3.6 corresponds to the average number of hydrogen bonds of each water molecule in pure solvent, computed in silico at 1 atm and 300 K. Note that this rough categorization is only useful when a solvation site is enthalpically unfavorable, given that the entropy of confined waters is almost always unfavorable relative to bulk, so it is likely that the free energy of that particular water site is also unfavorable relative to bulk. Conversely, if a solvation site appears to be enthalpically favorable, nothing can be concluded about its free energy in the absence of an entropy estimate. WATMD has recently been extended to allow quantification of both local and global solvation enthalpies and entropies (and thus free energies),(27) which should improve the level of understanding of solvation for future work.

      Why are long-acting beta-adrenoceptor agonists long-acting?
      Anderson, G. P.; Linden, A.; Rabe, K. F.
      European Respiratory Journal (1994), 7 (3), 569-78CODEN: ERJOEI; ISSN:0903-1936.
      A review with 60 refs. The extended duration of bronchodilation due to formoterol and salmeterol greatly exceeds that of short acting beta2-adrenoceptor agonists, such as salbutamol or terbutaline. This extended duration and their capacity to "reassert" airway smooth muscle relaxation in vitro despite repeated washing has prompted considerable debate on the underlying mechanism(s). The comparative pharmacol., and mol. modeling of these drugs and of the beta2-adrenoceptor and its ligand binding core have cast doubt on the exosite/exoceptor model previously proposed to explain the behavior of salmeterol. The authors present evidence supporting a unifying hypothesis that the duration of action both of formoterol and salmeterol is detd. principally by their physicochem. interactions with membrane lipid bilayers (plasmalemma diffusion microkinetic model), rather than putative distinct exosite/exoceptor binding sites in or near the beta2-adrenoceptor. This model provides a clearer understanding of the pharmacol. profile of these drugs (rate of onset, duration, "reassertion", interaction with hydrophilic and hydrophobic beta2-adrenoceptor antagonists), and explains why in human airway smooth muscle in vitro a true relaxation-concn. response may not exist for salmeterol.

      Observed drug-receptor association rates are governed by membrane affinity: the importance of establishing "micro-pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic relationships" at the β2-adrenoceptor
      Sykes, David A.; Parry, Cheryl; Reilly, John; Wright, Penny; Fairhurst, Robin A.; Charlton, Steven J.
      Molecular Pharmacology (2014), 85 (4), 608-617, 10 pp.CODEN: MOPMA3; ISSN:1521-0111. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Current pharmacol. models for detg. affinity and kinetics of drugs for membrane receptors assume the interacting mols. are homogeneously distributed in the bulk aq. phase. The phospholipid membrane can, however, provide a second compartment into which drugs can partition, particularly lipophilic/basic compds. In this study we measured the phospholipid affinity and receptor binding kinetics of several clin. relevant β2-adrenoceptor agonists and antagonists and demonstrated that the degree of phospholipid interaction directly affects the obsd. kinetic assocn. rate (kon) and dissocn. const. In conclusion, we propose a new approach to detg. the pharmacol. of drugs for membrane targets that accounts for differences in local drug concn. brought about by direct affinity for phospholipids, establishing "micro-pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic relationships" for drugs.

      Ligands, their receptors and ... plasma membranes
      Vauquelin, G.; Packeu, A.
      Molecular and Cellular Endocrinology (2009), 311 (1-2), 1-10CODEN: MCEND6; ISSN:0303-7207. (Elsevier Ireland Ltd.)
      A review. Ligand-receptor interactions are customarily described by equations that apply to solutes. Yet, most receptors are present in cell membranes so that sufficiently lipophilic ligands could reach the receptor by a 2-dimensional approach within the membrane. As summarized in this review, this may affect the ligand-receptor interaction in many ways. Biophysicists have calcd. that, compared to a 3-dimensional approach from the liq. phase, such an approach could alter the time the ligands need to find a receptor. Biochemists have found that ligand incorporation into lipid bilayers modifies their conformation. This, along with the depth at which the ligands reside in the bilayer, will affect the probability of successful receptor interaction. Novel mechanisms have also been introduced, including "exosite" binding and ligand translocation between the receptor α-helical transmembrane domains. Pharmacologists have focused attention at ligand concns. in the membrane, their adsorption and release rates, and the effects thereof on ligand potency and residence time at the receptor.

      Long-lasting target binding and rebinding as mechanisms to prolong in vivo drug action
      Vauquelin, Georges; Charlton, Steven J.
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2010), 161 (3), 488-508CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. An increasing no. of examples in the literature suggest that the in vivo duration of drug action not only depends on macroscopic pharmacokinetic properties like plasma half-life and the time needed to equilibrate between the plasma and the effect compartments, but is also influenced by long-lasting target binding and rebinding. The present review combines information from different research areas and simulations to explore the nature of these mechanisms and the conditions in which they are most prevalent. Simulations reveal that these latter phenomena become esp. influential when there is no longer sufficient free drug around to maintain high levels of receptor occupancy. There is not always a direct link between slow dissocn. and long-lasting in vivo target protection, as the rate of free drug elimination from the effect compartment is also a key influencing factor. Local phenomena that hinder the diffusion of free drug mols. away from their target may allow them to consecutively bind to the same target and/or targets nearby (denoted as 'rebinding') even when their concn. in the bulk phase has already dropped to insignificant levels. The micro-anat. properties of many effect compartments are likely to intensify this phenomenon. By mimicking the complexity of tissues, intact cells offer the opportunity to investigate both mechanisms under the same, physiol. relevant conditions.

      On the mechanism of the persistent action of salmeterol: what is the current position?
      Coleman, R. A.

      A review. The mechanism of the long duration of action of salmeterol at β2-adrenoceptors has long been a matter of debate, and is still unresolved. Szczuka and colleagues have both summarized the position to date and suggested a new mechanistic contender, receptor rebinding. Despite this, they still do not come to any clear conclusion. Much of the literature data that they have drawn upon appears contradictory, and math. models are inevitably flawed by the questionable validity of key values applied to them. Although the issue will undoubtedly eventually be resolved, it will probably require investigators to apply carefully designed studies on simple exptl. systems such as isolated membranes or cultured cells. Only then should studies be extended to more complex systems such as isolated prepns. of airways smooth muscle, where tissue bulk inevitably presents a complicating factor, particularly where relatively lipophilic compds. are concerned.

      Molecular mechanisms for the persistent bronchodilatory effect of the β2-adrenoceptor agonist salmeterol
      Szczuka, A.; Wennerberg, M.; Packeu, A.; Vauquelin, G.
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2009), 158 (1), 183-194CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      β2-adrenoceptor agonists are effective bronchodilators. In vitro studies demonstrated long-lasting airway smooth muscle relaxation by salmeterol after washout, the quick disappearance of this effect in presence of antagonists and its recovery after antagonist removal. Current explanations invoke salmeterol accumulation in the membrane ('diffusion microkinetic' model) or the existence of salmeterol-binding 'exosites'. An alternative model based on 'rebinding' of a dissocd. ligand to the receptor mols. also produces an apparent decrease in the ligand's dissocn. rate in the absence of competing ligands. Computer-assisted simulations were performed to follow the receptor-occupation by a salmeterol-like ligand and a competing ligand as a function of time. The aptness of the models to describe the above in vitro findings was evaluated. The 'diffusion microkinetic' model is sufficient to explain a long-lasting β2-adrenoceptor stimulation and reassertion as long as the membrane harbors a high concn. of the agonist. At lower concn., 'rebinding' and, in second place, 'exosite' binding are likely to become operational. The 'rebinding' and 'exosite' binding mechanisms take place at a sub-cellular/mol. scale. Pending their demonstration by expts. on appropriate, simple models such as intact cells or membranes thereof, these mechanisms remain hypothetical in the case of salmeterol. Airway smooth muscle contraction could also be governed by addnl. mechanisms that are particular to this macroscopic approach.

      Evidence for a non-β2-adrenoceptor binding site in human lung tissue for a subset of β2-adrenoceptor agonists

      Extent of salmeterol-mediated reassertion of relaxation in guinea pig trachea pretreated with aliphatic side chain structural analogs
      Bergendal, A.; Linden, A.; Skoogh, B.-E.; Gerspacher, M.; Anderson, G. P.; Loefdahl, C.-G.
      British Journal of Pharmacology (1996), 117 (6), 1009-15CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:0007-1188. (Stockton)
      Salmeterol is a potent, selective and long acting β2-adrenoceptor agonist. In vitro, salmeterol exerts 'reassertion' relaxation of airways smooth muscle. Reassertion relaxation refers to the capacity of salmeterol to cause repeated functional antagonism of induced contraction when airway smooth muscle is intermittently exposed to, then washed free from, β-adrenoceptor antagonists such as sotalol. The mechanism(s) underlying reassertion relaxation are unknown but may relate to high affinity binding of the long aliph. side chain of salmeterol to an accessory site, distinct from the agonist recognition site, in or near the β2-adrenoceptor (exosite binding hypothesis). To test the exosite hypothesis, three pure analogs of salmeterol, each exactly preserving the mol. structure of the aliph. side chain but with zero or low efficacy at the β2-adrenoceptor were synthesized. The effect of pre-incubating guinea-pig tracheal smooth muscle with these analogs on salmeterol-induced reassertion relaxation was detd. Computer Assisted Mol. Modeling of these mols. revealed that each of them exactly preserved the low energy linear conformation of the aliph. side chain of salmeterol. Measurement of lipophilicity (octanol:water partition coeff.; log P) and direct partition into synthetic membranes (membrane partition coeff.; Kpmem) showed that all compds. had high affinity for lipids and membranes. In particular the biophys. properties of CGP 59162 (log P 1.89, Kpmem 16500) were very similar to salmeterol (log P 1.73, Kpmem 16800). Two of the analogs, CGP 54103 and D 2543 (1 μM), which are structural mimics of the sie chain of salmeterol, differing slightly in their length, did not prevent either the initial relaxation induced by salmeterol (0.1 μM) or the reassertion relaxation; however, it was not possible to det. whether either of these mols. occupied the β2-adrenoceptor. The third analog, CGP 59162, which has the substituents on the active saligenin head group of salmeterol in transposed positions, itself exerted a weak β2-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxation antagonized by ICI 118551 (β2-selective antagonist) but not CGP 20712 (β1-selective antagonist) and, at higher concns. CGP 59162 caused reassertion relaxation suggesting that it may occupy and activate the β2-adrenoceptor in a manner analogous to salmeterol. CGP 59162, at concns. up to ten fold molar excess, did not prevent or reduce salmeterol-induced reassertion relaxation. In conclusion these data are not consistent with the existence of a distinct 'exosite' recognizing the aliph. side chain of salmeterol mediating reassertion.

      On the predictive value of experiments in vitro in the evaluation of the effect duration of bronchodilator drugs for local administration
      Jeppsson A B; Lofdahl C G; Waldeck B; Widmark E
      Pulmonary pharmacology (1989), 2 (2), 81-5 ISSN:0952-0600.
      Six bronchodilating beta-adrenoceptor agonists, clinically documented with respect to the duration of action after inhalation, were included in this study in vitro on the guinea-pig trachea. Relaxation of carbachol contracted trachea strip preparations and inhibition of contraction of a vagus nerve-tracheal tube preparation were measured. The relaxing effects of salbutamol and fenoterol (both with relatively short duration in man) were rapid in onset and easily reversed by washing in a drug-free medium. The relaxation by salmeterol (long duration) and D2343 (intermediate duration) developed more slowly, resisted washing but was reversed by propranolol. For the more lipophilic compounds formoterol, salmefamol, salmeterol and D2343, this difference was less pronounced. A high lipophilicity and a retention by the tissue in vitro of a beta-adrenoceptor agonist may be factors contributing to a long effect duration after inhalation but a further selection has to be made in vivo since metabolic and circulatory effects may influence the effect kinetics.

      Abdiche, Yasmina N.; Myszka, David G.
      Analytical Biochemistry (2004), 328 (2), 233-243CODEN: ANBCA2; ISSN:0003-2697. (Elsevier Science)
      Assay conditions were established to screen a panel of drugs for binding to liposome surfaces using a surface plasmon resonance (SPR) biosensor. Drugs were found to bind negligibly or reversibly or were retained on the liposome surface. Cationic amphiphilic drugs fell into the last class and correlated with drugs that induce phospholipidosis in vivo. To a first approxn., a single-site model yielded apparent binding affinities that adequately described a drug's dose-dependent binding to liposome surfaces. A comparison between the dissocn. of drugs from liposome surfaces by Biacore and the lipid retention measurements detd. by a parallel artificial membrane permeability assay was drawn. The results from this study demonstrate the potential of using SPR-based assays to characterize drug/liposome-binding interactions.

      The statistical-thermodynamic basis for computation of binding affinities: a critical review
      Gilson, Michael K.; Given, James A.; Bush, Bruce L.; Mccammon, J. Andrew
      Biophysical Journal (1997), 72 (3), 1047-1069CODEN: BIOJAU; ISSN:0006-3495. (Biophysical Society)
      A review with many refs. Although the statistical thermodn. of noncovalent binding has been considered in a no. of theor. papers, few methods of computing binding affinities are derived explicitly from this underlying theory. This has contributed to uncertainty and controversy in certain areas. This article therefore reviews and extends the connections of some important computational methods with the underlying statistical thermodn. A derivation of the std. free energy of binding forms the basis of this review. This derivation should be useful in formulating novel computational methods for predicting binding affinities. It is argued that mol. mass has a negligible effect upon the std. free energy of binding for biomol. systems, and that the cratic entropy defined by Gurney is not a useful concept. In addn., the use of continuum models of the solvent in binding calcns. is reviewed, and a formalism is presented for incorporating a limited no. of solvent mols. explicitly.

      Wang, Lingle; Wu, Yujie; Deng, Yuqing; Kim, Byungchan; Pierce, Levi; Krilov, Goran; Lupyan, Dmitry; Robinson, Shaughnessy; Dahlgren, Markus K.; Greenwood, Jeremy; Romero, Donna L.; Masse, Craig; Knight, Jennifer L.; Steinbrecher, Thomas; Beuming, Thijs; Damm, Wolfgang; Harder, Ed; Sherman, Woody; Brewer, Mark; Wester, Ron; Murcko, Mark; Frye, Leah; Farid, Ramy; Lin, Teng; Mobley, David L.; Jorgensen, William L.; Berne, Bruce J.; Friesner, Richard A.; Abel, Robert

      Designing tight-binding ligands is a primary objective of small-mol. drug discovery.       A review. Class A G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are thought to have a common topol. that includes seven transmembrane alpha helixes (TMHs) that are arranged to form a closed bundle. This bundle forms the ligand binding pocket into which ligands are commonly thought to enter via the extracellular milieu. This ligand approach direction makes sense for GPCRs that have small pos. charged ligands, such as the beta-2-adrenergic or the dopamine D2 receptor. However, there is a growing sub-group of Class A GPCRs that bind lipid-derived endogenous ligands, such as the cannabinoid CB1 and CB2 receptors (with endogenous ligands, N-arachidonoylethanolamine (anandamide) and sn-2-arachidonylglycerol (2-AG)) and the S1P1-5 receptors (with endogenous ligand, sphingosine-1-phosphate). For these receptors, ligand approach from the extracellular milieu has seemed unlikely given that the ligands of these receptors readily partition into lipid or are actually synthesized in the lipid bilayer. The recent X-ray-crystal structure of the sub-type 1 sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor (S1P1) provides important information on the key structural variations that may be the hallmarks for a Class A GPCR that binds lipid-derived ligands. These include an extracellular domain that is closed off to the extracellular milieu and the existence of an opening between transmembrane helixes that may serve as a portal for ligand entry via the lipid bilayer. This review examines structural aspects that the cannabinoid receptors may share with the S1P1 receptor based upon sequence homol. This review also examines exptl. and simulation results that suggest ligand entry via a lipid portal is quite likely for this emerging sub-group.

Plasma concns. of AD and desethylAD were approx. 4- and 12-fold higher, resp., in Fischer-344s compared to Sprague-Dawleys 24 h after the last dose. AD and desethylAD levels in AMs were approx. 12- and 25-fold higher, resp., in Fischer-344s than Sprague-Dawleys. In the liver and kidney, levels of both compds. were also significantly higher in Fischer-344s than Sprague-Dawleys. Ultrastructural features indicative of phospholipidosis were not obsd. consistently in any tissue except AMs from treated Fischer-344s. AM total phospholipid increased nearly 5-fold in Fischer-344s, while Sprague-Dawleys showed no increase over control. AMs from both strains incubated with 10 μM AD or desethylAD in vitro were not significantly different in their accumulation of the compds. When incubated with AD or desethylAD, the lysosomal phospholipases A1 partially purified from AMs of both strains were equally sensitive to inhibition as measured by the drug concn. giving 50% inhibition in activity (IC50). The results of this study indicate that at the same administered dose, AD and desethylAD, accumulate to higher tissue levels and are more phospholipogenic in male Fischer-344 rats than in male Sprague-Dawley rats. The basis for the high susceptibility of Fischer-344 rats to AM-induced phospholipidosis is unknown at present but appears not to be related to biochem. or cellular features of the AMs.

      Adrenaline-activated structure of β2-adrenoceptor stabilized by an engineered nanobody

      G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are integral membrane proteins that play an essential role in human physiol., yet the mol. processes through which they bind to their endogenous agonists and activate effector proteins remain poorly understood. The crystal structures revealed a highly conserved overall ligand recognition and activation mode despite diverse ligand chem. structures and affinities that ranged from 100 nM to ∼80 pM. Overall, the adrenaline-bound receptor structure was similar to the others, but it had substantial rearrangements in extracellular loop 3 and the extracellular tip of transmembrane helix 6. These structures also revealed a water-mediated H-bond between 2 conserved Tyr residues, which appeared to stabilize the active state of the β2AR and related GPCRs.

      Routine Microsecond Molecular Dynamics Simulations with AMBER on GPUs. 1. Generalized Born
      Gotz, Andreas W.; Williamson, Mark J.; Xu, Dong; Poole, Duncan; Le Grand, Scott; Walker, Ross C.
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2012), 8 (5), 1542-1555CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      We present an implementation of generalized Born implicit solvent all-atom classical mol. dynamics (MD) within the AMBER program package that runs entirely on CUDA enabled NVIDIA graphics processing units (GPUs). We discuss the algorithms that are used to exploit the processing power of the GPUs and show the performance that can be achieved in comparison to simulations on conventional CPU clusters. The implementation supports three different precision models in which the contributions to the forces are calcd. in single precision floating point arithmetic but accumulated in double precision (SPDP), or everything is computed in single precision (SPSP) or double precision (DPDP). In addn. to performance, we have focused on understanding the implications of the different precision models on the outcome of implicit solvent MD simulations. We show results for a range of tests including the accuracy of single point force evaluations and energy conservation as well as structural properties pertaining to protein dynamics. The numerical noise due to rounding errors within the SPSP precision model is sufficiently large to lead to an accumulation of errors which can result in unphys. trajectories for long time scale simulations. We recommend the use of the mixed-precision SPDP model since the numerical results obtained are comparable with those of the full double precision DPDP model and the ref. double precision CPU implementation but at significantly reduced computational cost. Our implementation provides performance for GB simulations on a single desktop that is on par with, and in some cases exceeds, that of traditional supercomputers.

      Salomon-Ferrer, Romelia; Gotz, Andreas W.; Poole, Duncan; Le Grand, Scott; Walker, Ross C.

      We present an implementation of explicit solvent all atom classical mol. dynamics (MD) within the AMBER program package that runs entirely on CUDA-enabled GPUs. Comm.2013, DOI: 10.1016/j.cpc.2012.09.022].We highlight the substantial improvements in performance that are seen over traditional CPU-only machines and provide validation of our implementation and precision models.       SPFP: Speed without compromise-A mixed precision model for GPU accelerated molecular dynamics simulations

      A new precision model is proposed for the acceleration of all-atom classical mol. dynamics (MD) simulations on graphics processing units (GPUs). This precision model replaces double precision arithmetic with fixed point integer arithmetic for the accumulation of force components as compared to a previously introduced model that uses mixed single/double precision arithmetic. MD as compared to a double precision CPU implementation and double and mixed single/double precision GPU implementations.

      ff14SB: Improving the Accuracy of Protein Side Chain and Backbone Parameters from ff99SB
      Maier, James A.; Martinez, Carmenza; Kasavajhala, Koushik; Wickstrom, Lauren; Hauser, Kevin E.; Simmerling, Carlos
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2015), 11 (8), 3696-3713CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      Mol. mechanics is powerful for its speed in atomistic simulations, but an accurate force field is required. The Amber ff99SB force field improved protein secondary structure balance and dynamics from earlier force fields like ff99, but weaknesses in side chain rotamer and backbone secondary structure preferences have been identified. Here, we performed a complete refit of all amino acid side chain dihedral parameters, which had been carried over from ff94. The training set of conformations included multidimensional dihedral scans designed to improve transferability of the parameters. Improvement in all amino acids was obtained as compared to ff99SB. Parameters were also generated for alternate protonation states of ionizable side chains. Av. errors in relative energies of pairs of conformations were under 1.0 kcal/mol as compared to QM, reduced 35% from ff99SB. We also took the opportunity to make empirical adjustments to the protein backbone dihedral parameters as compared to ff99SB. Multiple small adjustments of φ and ψ parameters were tested against NMR scalar coupling data and secondary structure content for short peptides. The best results were obtained from a phys. motivated adjustment to the φ rotational profile that compensates for lack of ff99SB QM training data in the β-ppII transition region. Together, these backbone and side chain modifications (hereafter called ff14SB) not only better reproduced their benchmarks, but also improved secondary structure content in small peptides and reprodn. of NMR χ1 scalar coupling measurements for proteins in soln. We also discuss the Amber ff12SB parameter set, a preliminary version of ff14SB that includes most of its improvements.

      Fast, efficient generation of high-quality atomic charges. AM1-BCC model: I. Method
      Jakalian, Araz; Bush, Bruce L.; Jack, David B.; Bayly, Christopher I.
      Journal of Computational Chemistry (2000), 21 (2), 132-146CODEN: JCCHDD; ISSN:0192-8651. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      The AM1-BCC method quickly and efficiently generates high-quality at. charges for use in condensed-phase simulations. The underlying features of the electron distribution including formal charge and delocalization are first captured by AM1 at. charges for the individual mol. Bond charge corrections (BCCs), which have been parameterized against the HF/6-31G* electrostatic potential (ESP) of a training set of compds. contg. relevant functional groups, are then added using a formalism identical to the consensus BCI (bond charge increment) approach. As a proof of the concept, we fit BCCs simultaneously to 45 compds. including O-, N-, and S-contg. functionalities, aroms., and heteroaroms., using only 41 BCC parameters. AM1-BCC yields charge sets of comparable quality to HF/6-31G* ESP-derived charges in a fraction of the time while reducing instabilities in the at. charges compared to direct ESP-fit methods. We then apply the BCC parameters to a small "test set" consisting of aspirin, D-glucose, and eryodictyol; the AM1-BCC model again provides at. charges of quality comparable with HF/6-31G* RESP charges, as judged by an increase of only 0.01 to 0.02 at. units in the root-mean-square (RMS) error in ESP. Based on these encouraging results, we intend to parameterize the AM1-BCC model to provide a consistent charge model for any org. or biol. mol.

      Fast, efficient generation of high-quality atomic charges. AM1-BCC model: II. parameterization and validation
      Jakalian, Araz; Jack, David B.; Bayly, Christopher I.
      Journal of Computational Chemistry (2002), 23 (16), 1623-1641CODEN: JCCHDD; ISSN:0192-8651. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      We present the first global parameterization and validation of a novel charge model, called AM1-BCC, which quickly and efficiently generates high-quality at. charges for computer simulations of org. mols. in polar media. The goal of the charge model is to produce at. charges that emulate the HF/6-31G* electrostatic potential (ESP) of a mol. Underlying electronic structure features, including formal charge and electron delocalization, are first captured by AM1 population charges; simple additive bond charge corrections (BCCs) are then applied to these AM1 at. charges to produce the AM1-BCC charges. The parameterization of BCCs was carried out by fitting to the HF/6-31G* ESP of a training set of >2700 mols. Most org. functional groups and their combinations were sampled, as well as an extensive variety of cyclic and fused bicyclic heteroaryl systems. The resulting BCC parameters allow the AM1-BCC charging scheme to handle virtually all types of org. compds. listed in The Merck Index and the NCI Database. Validation of the model was done through comparisons of hydrogen-bonded dimer energies and relative free energies of solvation using AM1-BCC charges in conjunction with the 1994 Cornell et al. forcefield for AMBER. Homo-dimer and hetero-dimer hydrogen-bond energies of a diverse set of org. mols. were reproduced to within 0.95 kcal/mol RMS deviation from the ab initio values, and for DNA dimers the energies were within 0.9 kcal/mol RMS deviation from ab initio values. The calcd. relative free energies of solvation for a diverse set of monofunctional isosteres were reproduced to within 0.69 kcal/mol of expt. In all these validation tests, AMBER with the AM1-BCC charge model maintained a correlation coeff. above 0.96. Thus, the parameters presented here for use with the AM1-BCC method present a fast, accurate, and robust alternative to HF/6-31G* ESP-fit charges for general use with the AMBER force field in computer simulations involving org. small mols.

      Toward Automated Benchmarking of Atomistic Force Fields: Neat Liquid Densities and Static Dielectric Constants from the ThermoML Data Archive
      Beauchamp, Kyle A.; Behr, Julie M.; Rustenburg, Arien S.; Bayly, Christopher I.; Kroenlein, Kenneth; Chodera, John D.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2015), 119 (40), 12912-12920CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      Atomistic mol. simulations are a powerful way to make quant. predictions, but the accuracy of these predictions depends entirely on the quality of the force field employed. Although exptl. measurements of fundamental phys. properties offer a straightforward approach for evaluating force field quality, the bulk of this information has been tied up in formats that are not machine-readable. Compiling benchmark data sets of phys. properties from non-machine-readable sources requires substantial human effort and is prone to the accumulation of human errors, hindering the development of reproducible benchmarks of force-field accuracy. The results of even this limited initial benchmark highlight a general problem with fixed-charge force fields in the representation low-dielec. environments, such as those seen in binding cavities or biol. membranes.

      GAFFlipid: a General Amber Force Field for the accurate molecular dynamics simulation of phospholipid
      Dickson, Callum J.; Rosso, Lula; Betz, Robin M.; Walker, Ross C.; Gould, Ian R.

      Previous attempts to simulate phospholipid bilayers using the General Amber Force Field (GAFF) yielded many bilayer characteristics in agreement with expt., however when using a tensionless NPT ensemble the bilayer is seen to compress to an undesirable extent resulting in low areas per lipid and high order parameters in comparison to expt. This preliminary work is intended for combination with the new AMBER Lipid11 modular force field as part of on-going attempts to create a modular phospholipid AMBER force field allowing tensionless NPT simulations of complex lipid bilayers.

      LIPID11: A Modular Framework for Lipid Simulations Using Amber
      Skjevik, Aage A.; Madej, Benjamin D.; Walker, Ross C.; Teigen, Knut
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2012), 116 (36), 11124-11136CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-5207. (American Chemical Society)
      Accurate simulation of complex lipid bilayers has long been a goal in condensed phase mol. dynamics (MD). Structure and function of membrane-bound proteins are highly dependent on the lipid bilayer environment and are challenging to study through exptl. methods. Within Amber, there has been limited focus on lipid simulations, although some success has been seen with the use of the General Amber Force Field (GAFF). However, to date there are no dedicated Amber lipid force fields. In this paper we describe a new charge derivation strategy for lipids consistent with the Amber RESP approach and a new atom and residue naming and type convention. In the first instance, we have combined this approach with GAFF parameters. The result is LIPID11, a flexible, modular framework for the simulation of lipids that is fully compatible with the existing Amber force fields. The charge derivation procedure, capping strategy, and nomenclature for LIPID11, along with preliminary simulation results and a discussion of the planned long-term parameter development are presented here. Our findings suggest that LIPID11 is a modular framework feasible for phospholipids and a flexible starting point for the development of a comprehensive, Amber-compatible lipid force field.

      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2014), 10 (2), 865-879CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)

      Grid inhomogeneous solvation theory: Hydration structure and thermodynamics of the miniature receptor cucurbit[7]uril
      Nguyen, Crystal N.; Kurtzman Young, Tom; Gilson, Michael K.
      Journal of Chemical Physics (2012), 137 (4), 044101/1-044101/17CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
      The displacement of perturbed water upon binding is believed to play a crit. role in the thermodn. of biomol. recognition, but it is nontrivial to unambiguously define and answer questions about this process. We address this issue by introducing grid inhomogeneous solvation theory (GIST), which discretizes the equations of inhomogeneous solvation theory (IST) onto a three-dimensional grid situated in the region of interest around a solute mol. or complex. Snapshots from explicit solvent simulations are used to est. localized solvation entropies, energies, and free energies assocd. with the grid boxes, or voxels, and properly summing these thermodn. quantities over voxels yields information about hydration thermodn. GIST thus provides a smoothly varying representation of water properties as a function of position, rather than focusing on hydration sites where solvent is present at high d. It therefore accounts for full or partial displacement of water from sites that are highly occupied by water, as well as for partly occupied and water-depleted regions around the solute. GIST can also provide a well-defined est. of the solvation free energy and therefore enables a rigorous end-states anal. of binding. For example, one may not only use a first GIST calcn. to project the thermodn. consequences of displacing water from the surface of a receptor by a ligand, but also account, in a second GIST calcn., for the thermodn. of subsequent solvent reorganization around the bound complex. In the present study, a first GIST anal. of the mol. host cucurbit7uril is found to yield a rich picture of hydration structure and thermodn. in and around this miniature receptor. One of the most striking results is the observation of a toroidal region of high water d. at the center of the host's nonpolar cavity. Despite its high d., the water in this toroidal region is disfavored energetically and entropically, and hence may contribute to the known ability of this small receptor to bind guest mols. with unusually high affinities. Interestingly, the toroidal region of high water d. persists even when all partial charges of the receptor are set to zero. Thus, localized regions of high solvent d. can be generated in a binding site without strong, attractive solute-solvent interactions. (c) 2012 American Institute of Physics.

Inhomogeneous fluid solvation theory provides a framework to derive thermodn. properties of individual water mols. from a statistical mech. anal. In this work, two biomols. are analyzed to probe the distribution and thermodn. of surrounding water mols. The great majority of hydration sites are predicted to contribute favorably to the total free energy with respect to bulk water, though hydration sites close to non-polar regions of the solute do not contribute significantly. Anal. of a biomol. with a pos. and neg. charged functional group predicts that a charged species perturbs the free energy of water mols. to a distance of approx. 6.0 Å. Interestingly, short simulations are found to provide converged predictions if samples are taken with sufficient frequency, a finding that has the potential to significantly reduce the required computational cost of such anal. In addn., the predicted thermodn. properties of hydration sites with the potential for direct hydrogen bonding interactions are found to disagree significantly for two different water models. This study provides important information on how inhomogeneous fluid solvation theory can be employed to understand the structures and intermol. interactions of biomols.

      Prediction of Small Molecule Hydration Thermodynamics with Grid Cell Theory
      Gerogiokas, Georgios; Calabro, Gaetano; Henchman, Richard H.; Southey, Michelle W. Y.; Law, Richard J.; Michel, Julien
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2014), 10 (1), 35-48CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      An efficient methodol. has been developed to quantify water energetics by anal. of explicit solvent mol. simulations of org. and biomol. systems. The approach, grid cell theory (GCT), relies on a discretization of the cell theory methodol. on a three-dimensional grid to spatially resolve the d., enthalpy, and entropy of water mols. in the vicinity of solute(s) of interest. Entropies of hydration are found to converge more efficiently than enthalpies of hydration. GCT predictions of free energies of hydration on a data set of small mols. are strongly correlated with thermodn. integration predictions. Agreement with the expt. is comparable for both approaches. A key advantage of GCT is its ability to provide from a single simulation insightful graphical analyses of spatially resolved components of the enthalpies and entropies of hydration.

      Water in Cavity-Ligand Recognition
      Baron, Riccardo; Setny, Piotr; Andrew McCammon, J.

        Why are long-acting beta-adrenoceptor agonists long-acting?
        Anderson, G. P.; Linden, A.; Rabe, K. F.
        European Respiratory Journal (1994), 7 (3), 569-78CODEN: ERJOEI; ISSN:0903-1936.
        A review with 60 refs. The extended duration of bronchodilation due to formoterol and salmeterol greatly exceeds that of short acting beta2-adrenoceptor agonists, such as salbutamol or terbutaline. This extended duration and their capacity to "reassert" airway smooth muscle relaxation in vitro despite repeated washing has prompted considerable debate on the underlying mechanism(s). The comparative pharmacol., and mol. modeling of these drugs and of the beta2-adrenoceptor and its ligand binding core have cast doubt on the exosite/exoceptor model previously proposed to explain the behavior of salmeterol. The authors present evidence supporting a unifying hypothesis that the duration of action both of formoterol and salmeterol is detd. principally by their physicochem. interactions with membrane lipid bilayers (plasmalemma diffusion microkinetic model), rather than putative distinct exosite/exoceptor binding sites in or near the beta2-adrenoceptor. This model provides a clearer understanding of the pharmacol. profile of these drugs (rate of onset, duration, "reassertion", interaction with hydrophilic and hydrophobic beta2-adrenoceptor antagonists), and explains why in human airway smooth muscle in vitro a true relaxation-concn. response may not exist for salmeterol.

        Ligands, their receptors and ... plasma membranes
        Vauquelin, G.; Packeu, A.

        A review. Ligand-receptor interactions are customarily described by equations that apply to solutes. Yet, most receptors are present in cell membranes so that sufficiently lipophilic ligands could reach the receptor by a 2-dimensional approach within the membrane. As summarized in this review, this may affect the ligand-receptor interaction in many ways. Biophysicists have calcd. that, compared to a 3-dimensional approach from the liq. phase, such an approach could alter the time the ligands need to find a receptor. Biochemists have found that ligand incorporation into lipid bilayers modifies their conformation. This, along with the depth at which the ligands reside in the bilayer, will affect the probability of successful receptor interaction. Novel mechanisms have also been introduced, including "exosite" binding and ligand translocation between the receptor α-helical transmembrane domains. Pharmacologists have focused attention at ligand concns. in the membrane, their adsorption and release rates, and the effects thereof on ligand potency and residence time at the receptor.

        13
        Long-lasting target binding and rebinding as mechanisms to prolong in vivo drug action
        Vauquelin, Georges; Charlton, Steven J.
        British Journal of Pharmacology (2010), 161 (3), 488-508CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        A review. An increasing no. of examples in the literature suggest that the in vivo duration of drug action not only depends on macroscopic pharmacokinetic properties like plasma half-life and the time needed to equilibrate between the plasma and the effect compartments, but is also influenced by long-lasting target binding and rebinding. The present review combines information from different research areas and simulations to explore the nature of these mechanisms and the conditions in which they are most prevalent. Simulations reveal that these latter phenomena become esp. influential when there is no longer sufficient free drug around to maintain high levels of receptor occupancy. There is not always a direct link between slow dissocn. and long-lasting in vivo target protection, as the rate of free drug elimination from the effect compartment is also a key influencing factor. Local phenomena that hinder the diffusion of free drug mols. away from their target may allow them to consecutively bind to the same target and/or targets nearby (denoted as 'rebinding') even when their concn. in the bulk phase has already dropped to insignificant levels. The micro-anat. properties of many effect compartments are likely to intensify this phenomenon. By mimicking the complexity of tissues, intact cells offer the opportunity to investigate both mechanisms under the same, physiol. relevant conditions.

        On the mechanism of the persistent action of salmeterol: what is the current position?
        Coleman, R. A.
